title: What is the solution of the system of equations: y = –5x + 6 y = –3x – 4? - Quora

response.answer_text: The first equation is y=-5x+6y and the second equation is y=-3x-4. Add -6y to both sides of the first equation and get y-6y=6y-6y-5x. Do the arithmetic and you get -5y=-5x. Divide both sides of this equation by -5 and you get y=x. Now use this result in the second equation (that is, insert y=x). This yields x=-3x+4. Now add +3x to both sides of that equation and get x+3x=3x-3x+4. Once again do the arithmetic and get 4x=0+4 or 4x=4. Divide both side of this final equation and the result is x=1. So the answer is y=x=1.

The question is to find an (x, y) at which the two equations intersect. y = -5x + 6 y = -3x - 4 So -5x + 6 = -3x - 4 -5x + 3x = -4 - 6 -2x = -10 x = (-10)/(-2) x = 5 If x = 5 then Using 1st equation y = -5(5) + 6 y = -25 + 6 y = -19 Using 2nd equation y = -3(5) - 4 y = -15 - 4 y = -19 Therefore the 2 equations intersect at (5, -19)
Both x and y are -1. y= -5x + 6y -5y = -5x, at this step, both x and y are the same number, but we don’t know if they are negative, positive, or just 0. Then, y = -3x - 4 y + 3x = -4 Here x = y = -1
set both equal to each other to find x: -5x+6 = -3x-4-2x = -10x=5 plug that value into one of the equations: y=-3(5) - 4 = -15 - 4 = -19 your solution is (5,-19).
